channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Not Only for Killing: Drones Are Now Detecting Land Mines in Ukraine
item.description: Ukraine is a beta test for embedding artificial intelligence and other new technologies in drones and robots to find deadly land mines, saving lives and allowing military forces to advance more quickly.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: An agricultural drone carrying a magnetic sensor to help survey land for mines last year during a demonstration in the Zhytomyr region of Ukraine.

item.title: Wild Boars Are Wreaking Havoc in Scotland’s Countryside
item.description: Local residents say the animals are roaming the roads and hills around the lake, tearing up lawns and terrorizing sheep.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Robert Sanderson and Grant Clark, unseen, retrieving a boar they shot near Loch Ness, in Scotland.

item.title: Authorities Open Manslaughter Investigation in Italy Yacht Sinking
item.description: A prosecutor involved in the inquiry into the sinking said it was “plausible” that crimes were committed during the accident.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:description: Rescue personnel transporting a bag believed to hold the body of Hannah Lynch, the daughter of the British tech entrepreneur Mike Lynch, on Friday off Porticello, Sicily.

item.title: What We Know About the Knife Attack in Germany That Killed 3
item.description: The police on Saturday evening arrested a man in connection with the case, but declined to say whether they believe he was the attacker in the stabbings at a city festival.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: A forensics team at a crime scene in Solingen, Germany.

item.title: In Lebanese Refugee Community, People See Hope in Hamas
item.description: In Ein al-Hilweh, Lebanon, long mired in poverty and despair, Hamas recruitment is up and the downtrodden air has given way to defiance and celebration.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib and Hwaida Saad
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Images of the Qassam Brigades spokesman, Abu Ubaida, on the right in this mural in Bourj al-Barajne, are a common sight in Palestinian refugee communities in Lebanon.

item.title: Explosions Outside a France Synagogue Were a Terrorist Attack, Prosecutors Say
item.description: Politicians quickly condemned the attack, at a time when antisemitic incidents have been on the rise in France.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Law enforcement officials near a building that was damaged in the attack on the synagogue in Le Grande Motte, France, on Saturday.

item.title: Zelensky Independence Day Speech Praises Ukraine’s Russia Offensive
item.description: Although the cross-border offensive carries risks, it also paid dividends on Saturday with the first prisoner swap with Russia in several months.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Ukrainians in Kyiv’s Independence Square commemorated fallen fighters during Independence Day celebrations on Saturday.

item.title: Mexico’s President Bet Big on Oil. His Successor Will Be Stuck With the Tab.
item.description: Mexico’s next leader, Claudia Sheinbaum, is a climate scientist who has signaled a clean energy pivot. But a huge wager on fossil fuels by her political mentor stands in her way.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero
item.media:description: The Olmeca oil refinery belonging to Pemex, the state-controlled oil company, in Paraiso, Mexico.

item.title: Hamas Agrees to Meet With Mediators in Cairo Ahead of Cease-Fire Talks
item.description: Fighting has raged in Gaza even as the United States, Qatar and Egypt have pushed for a deal, with Israeli strikes overnight killing dozens, according to health officials in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: A car buried in rubble after an Israeli airstrike in Nuseirat, in central Gaza, on Thursday.

item.title: Bus Accident in Nepal Kills at Least 27
item.description: Nepal, a poor and mountainous country, has long struggled with road safety.
item.dc:creator: Bhadra Sharma
item.media:description: Rescue workers raising an injured passenger to safety in Nepal, where on Friday a bus carrying tourists from India went off the road and fell into a river at the bottom of a gorge.

item.title: Bus in Cambodia Is a Mobile Museum of Khmer Rouge Crimes
item.description: Most people in Cambodia are under 30, born long after the horrific rule of the Khmer Rouge. A bus is touring the country to make sure it’s not forgotten.
item.dc:creator: Anton L. Delgado
item.category: Extraordinary Chambers in the Courts of Cambodia
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Thomas Cristofoletti for The New York Times
item.media:description: Students in Angkor Chey, Cambodia, learning about the Khmer Rouge last month. A bus with access to a digital archive from the period is visiting schools across the country.

item.title: Russia Quashes Deadly Prison Mutiny by Islamist Inmates
item.description: The revolt is the latest in a series of terrorist attacks in Russia claimed by Islamic militants.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Oleg Matsnev
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: An image taken from video released by Russian state media showed security officers inside Penal Colony No. 19 in Volgograd, Russia, where inmates mutinied and killed several guards on Friday.

item.title: How to Be Truly Free: Lessons From a Philosopher President
item.description: Pepe Mujica, Uruguay’s spartan former president and plain-spoken philosopher, offers wisdom from a rich life as he battles cancer.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Dado Galdieri

item.title: Two Armed Rebels Who Led a Nation: A Love Story
item.description: José Mujica and Lucía Topolansky have long been married to one another — and their leftist political cause.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: José Mujica, left, and Lucía Topolansky belonged to a leftist guerrilla group, the Tupamaros, when they met in the early 1970s.

item.title: Out of Season
item.description: Summer’s coming to a close soon. You’re still, to some extent, in control of how you spend the time.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: With Freight Off the Rails, Rare Open Tracks for Passenger Trains
item.description: The brief lockout of freight railway workers gave Via Rail Canada trains a temporary reprieve from their second-class status.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Unlike Amtrak, Via Rail’s trains don’t have priority over freight.

item.title: South Korean Beekeepers Find Meaning Working Near the DMZ
item.description: The heavily fortified area separating North and South Korea is home to a biodiverse landscape and is a place of deep meaning for nearby farmers whose bees can fly freely through it.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives, Youmi Kim and Jun Michael Park
item.media:credit: Jun Michael Park for The New York Times

item.title: Knife Attack in Germany Kills at Least 3 at Solingen Festival
item.description: The attack took place in Solingen during a celebration of the 650th anniversary of the city’s founding. Eight people were wounded.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze

item.title: Why Mpox Vaccines Aren’t Flowing to Africans in Desperate Need
item.description: Drugmakers have supplies ready to ship that are necessary to stop a potential pandemic. But W.H.O. regulations have slowed access.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen
item.media:description: A health worker prepared a dose of the mpox vaccine at a medical center in Paris last month. The vaccine is widely available in the West but not in Africa.

item.title: Israel Presses for Gaza Border Presence as Part of Cease-Fire Deal
item.description: Mediators in truce negotiations, including the C.I.A. director and President Biden’s Middle East envoy, are seeking a summit next week to keep the struggling talks alive.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman and Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers near the Israeli-Gazan border on Friday.

item.title: Sudan’s Military Spurns Cease-Fire Talks in Switzerland
item.description: American-led mediators secured famine relief for needy areas. But with Sudan’s military failing to attend, a cease-fire was far out of reach.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:description: Cease-fire talks for Sudan were convened by the U.S. envoy to Sudan, Tom Perriello, center. He appeared at a closing news conference with Sibylle Obrist, left, the head of the Swiss delegation, and Ali bin Hassan Jafar, the head of the Saudi delegation.

item.title: U.S. Tightens Technology Controls to Target Russian War Machine
item.description: The Biden administration announced new penalties on shell companies and suppliers that were feeding Russia’s war against Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Anthony Kwan for The New York Times
item.media:description: 135 Bonham Strand in Hong Kong. The office was the place of registration for companies that funneled millions of restricted chips and sensors to military technology companies in Russia, a New York Times investigation found.

item.title: Lucie Castets Wants to Be France’s Prime Minister but Needs Emmanuel Macron’s Backing
item.description: Lucie Castets, a relatively obscure bureaucrat, is the left’s choice to be prime minister. Just one person stands in her way: the president.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:description: Lucie Castets is the New Popular Front’s candidate for prime minister of France. She has been doing something political analysts say they’ve never seen: campaigning for the job.

item.title: As Ukraine Pushes Into Russia, Its Next Steps Are Unclear
item.description: American officials are not convinced that Ukraine intends to hold its position in Russia long term.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt, Helene Cooper and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier patrolling in Sudzha, a town in western Russia, this month. U.S. officials and analysts said that the more territory Ukraine captures, the harder it will be to defend.

item.title: Hostage Families and Others in Israel Say They’ll Boycott Oct. 7 Government Memorial
item.description: Relatives of hostages being held in Gaza and some communities on Israel’s southern border argue the Israeli government should focus on freeing their loved ones.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Burned vehicles at Kibbutz Nir Oz, along Israel’s southern border near Gaza, in October.

item.title: What to Know About the Business Execs Who Were With Mike Lynch on His Yacht
item.description: The two business figures, both associates of the tech mogul, went missing after the superyacht they were on sank off the coast of Sicily.
item.dc:creator: Michael J. de la Merced
item.media:description: Rescue personnel transporting a body bag after a luxury yacht carrying the British entrepreneur Mike Lynch and 21 others sank off the coast near Palermo, Sicily.

item.title: Jake Sullivan, Biden’s National Security Adviser, Will Visit China Next Week
item.description: A final meeting between President Biden and China’s leader, Xi Jinping, is also likely to come up.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: Jake Sullivan trip will be his fifth face-to-face meeting with Wang Yi, China’s foreign minister, but his only trip to Beijing since the start of the Biden administration.

item.title: Ukraine Steps Up Strikes Into Russia as Moscow Pushes Ahead in the East
item.description: Ukraine struck a port across from Crimea and damaged a cargo ferry. But Kyiv’s forces continued to struggle in eastern areas under a relentless Russian assault.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: People carry children as local residents rush to board an evacuation train on Thursday amid Russian troop advances in Pokrovsk, Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: Deadly Floods Strike Troubled Bangladesh
item.description: Disaster has hit just weeks after mass protests led to a lethal crackdown and then prompted the abrupt flight of the long-serving prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Saif Hasnat
item.media:credit: Munir Uz Zaman/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: People wading through floodwaters in Feni, Bangladesh, on Friday.

item.title: Final Body Is Recovered From Yacht That Sank Off Sicily
item.description: Hannah Lynch, the 18-year-old daughter of the British tech entrepreneur Mike Lynch, was on board a yacht that was hit by a storm and went down in the early hours on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: A bag believed to hold the body of Hannah Lynch, daughter of the British tech entrepreneur Mike Lynch, off Porticello, Sicily, on Friday.

item.title: Indian Leader Visits Kyiv as Ukraine Pushes Diplomacy
item.description: Ukrainian officials were portraying the visit by Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India as a welcome show of support for their country during the war with Russia.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine welcomed Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India in Kyiv on Friday.

item.title: With $20 Billion Weapons Deal, U.S. Aims to Help Israel and Deter Iran
item.description: The White House has told Congress it is allowing the sale of $20 billion in arms to Israel. Here’s what’s in the package.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:description: An Israeli soldier carries a mortar shell on Wednesday before firing into Gaza, near the Israel-Gaza border.

item.title: Scientists Made a List of Lost Birds and Now They Want Us to Find Them
item.description: Some 144 bird species had not been seen in at least a decade, but a project by conservation organizations proposes they all may still be hidden somewhere in the wild.
item.dc:creator: Jim Robbins

item.title: Sydney Metro Expands, Opening to Celebrity-Level Fanfare
item.description: In a mostly car-dependent country where public transportation in major cities can be best described as “decent,” the expansion felt momentous.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Passengers disembarking from the newly opened metro line at the Chatswood station in Sydney, Australia.

item.title: South Korea Battery Plant Rushed Production Before Deadly Fire, Police Say
item.description: The fire, one of the country’s worst industrial disasters in recent years, happened as the factory was rushing to fulfill a military contract, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:description: Firefighters in June at the lithium battery factory where 23 workers died in Hwaseong, South Korea.

item.title: On Gaza, Democrats’ Most Divisive Issue, Harris Embraces Biden’s Balancing Act
item.description: With her party torn between pro-Israel Democrats and younger progressives, she’s looking for a way to quiet one major issue until after the election.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: “I will always stand up for Israel’s right to defend itself,” Kamala Harris said during her speech on Thursday night, before acknowledging the “devastating” damage and “innocent lives lost” as the Israelis retaliated.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: The final night of the Democratic National Convention.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris in Chicago last night.

item.title: Families of Dead Hostages Vent Anger at Israeli Leaders Over War
item.description: After Israel recovered the bodies of six men who died in Hamas captivity in Gaza, survivors accused the government of sinking the chances of hostages returning alive through a cease-fire deal.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ruti Munder reading a eulogy on Wednesday for her husband, Abraham, as their daughter, Keren, steadied the paper, at his funeral in Nir Oz, Israel.

item.title: A History Museum Shows How China Wants to Remake Hong Kong
item.description: A new exhibit calls for the city’s residents to be patriotic, loyal to the Chinese Communist Party and ever vigilant to supposed threats to the state.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.media:credit: Anthony Kwan for The New York Times
item.media:description: A new exhibit on national security at the Hong Kong Museum of History.

item.title: Volcano Erupts Near Fishing Town in Iceland
item.description: The latest eruption, the sixth since December, is part of increased volcanic activity that began in 2021.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Hurtes and Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse, via Public Defense Department of the State Police in Iceland
item.media:description: A volcano near the town of Grindavik, in southwestern Iceland, erupted this week.

item.title: Nepal Lifts Ban on TikTok, in a Likely Overture to China
item.description: The move signaled that Nepal’s new prime minister, who has cultivated ties with China, would continue on that path.
item.dc:creator: Bhadra Sharma
item.media:description: Prime Minister K.P. Sharma Oli of Nepal reversed a ban on TikTok, which was asked to abide by certain rules.

item.title: Israel Orders New Evacuations, Forcing Gazans to Flee Again
item.description: As the Israeli military ordered people to leave parts of central and southern Gaza, a surgeon said that hospital workers were asking, “Where can we go, what are we going to do?”
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim, Abu Bakr Bashir and Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Palestinian women mourn a relative killed in the Israeli bombardment of the Gaza Strip, at a hospital in Deir al-Balah, on Thursday.

item.title: What I’m reading: A ‘Book of the Century’ I’d Somehow Missed
item.description: “The Last Samurai,” which has nothing to do with the Tom Cruise movie of the same name, is as good as everyone says.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Richard Baker/In Pictures, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Passengers on the London Underground in the 1990s. The main characters in Helen DeWitt’s novel “The Last Samurai” spend entire days riding the Circle Line.

item.title: Russia Opens New Cases Against Journalists Who Covered Ukrainian Incursion
item.description: Moscow said it was investigating three more reporters, including a CNN correspondent, who crossed into Russian territory to cover the fighting.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: A crossing point on the border with Russia in the Sumy region of Ukraine this month.

item.title: Ukraine Cites Modi Visit as the Fruit of an Emerging Diplomatic Push
item.description: Officials say efforts to engage neutral nations like India along with the military incursion into Russia will strengthen Ukraine’s hand in any peace talks.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India in Warsaw on Wednesday. He is scheduled to visit Kyiv on Friday.

item.title: Friday Briefing: A Brutal Reality for Women in India
item.description: Plus, saying goodbye to a penguin and an icon.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.media:description: A vigil for the murdered woman in Guwahati, India, on Saturday.

item.title: Autopsies of 6 Bodies Recovered From Gaza Reveal Bullets, Advocacy Group for Hostage Families Says
item.description: The assertion raised new questions about how the Israeli hostages died. An Israeli military spokesperson stressed that it was too soon to determine whether gunshot wounds were the cause of death.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni and Johnatan Reiss
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ruti Munder, right, near her husband’s grave in Kibbutz Nir Oz, Israel, on Wednesday.

item.title: Diamond Found in Botswana Is World’s 2nd-Largest Ever at 2,492 Carats
item.description: The diamond was unearthed using new technology, and miners hope it will bring back luster to a struggling industry.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel

item.title: Are Researchers Overcounting the Number of Fish in the World’s Oceans?
item.description: A new study suggests that estimates of the health of the world’s fisheries may be too optimistic.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Andreoni
item.media:description: Organizing a haul from the North Sea aboard the Radiant Star fishing vessel off the coast of Shetland, Scotland.

item.title: Venezuela’s Loyalist Supreme Court Certifies Maduro’s Election Win
item.description: The court did not share voting data to back up its decision despite demands from Venezuelans and international election observers that the government produce evidence of his victory.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz and Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:description: Caryslia Rodríguez, president of Venezuela’s top court, declares Mr. Maduro the winner in July’s presidential vote.

item.title: Many Climate Policies Struggle to Cut Emissions, Study Finds
item.description: The most effective ones tend to combine several emissions-cutting strategies, not a stand-alone approach, according to an examination of 1,500 policies globally.
item.dc:creator: Austyn Gaffney
item.media:description: The Drax Power Station, a former coal plant that has been converted to burn biomass pellets, in Selby, England.

item.title: TikTok Cucumber Salad Trend Sets Off Shortage in Iceland Groceries
item.description: Icelandic cooks, eager to try the latest social media trend, are amused and a little surprised by their empty produce aisles.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Christopher Testani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cucumbers are missing from produce aisles across Iceland.

item.title: Russian Attitudes About Putin Might Be Shifting
item.description: Negative remarks on social media have increased since Ukrainian troops launched an incursion, according to a firm that tracks Russian attitudes.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: A heavily damaged statue of Vladimir Lenin in Sudzha, Russia, after Ukrainian troops crossed the border in a counteroffensive this month.

item.title: Silvio Santos, Provocative Brazilian Television Host, Dies at 93
item.description: He was best known for the long-running variety show “Programa Silvio Santos,” on which he charmed his audiences with gimmicks and showcased a range of performers.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.media:description: Silvio Santos in an undated photo. A beloved Brazilian television personality, he spent more than six decades in front of the camera.

item.title: Germany’s Aid to Ukraine Comes Under New Strain
item.description: With a budget shortfall for 2025 and evidence mounting that Ukraine blew up natural-gas pipelines between Germany and Russia, German aid to Ukraine is under pressure.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Germany, which has been Europe’s largest supporter of Ukraine since the start of the Russian invasion, hosted the Ukrainian soldiers seen here for training on the Patriot antiaircraft missile system at a military training ground in Mecklenburg, Germany.

item.title: Thailand Confirms First Case of New, Deadlier Mpox Strain, Clade 1b
item.description: The Clade Ib version of the virus had not been detected outside Africa until last week, when a case in Sweden raised concerns about a wider outbreak.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:description: Dr. Thongchai Keeratihuttayakorn, the general director of Thailand’s disease control department, at a news conference on Wednesday.

item.title: Crew Rescued, but Oil Tanker Attacked in Red Sea Is ‘Environmental Hazard’
item.description: The incident appeared to be the most serious in weeks involving commercial shipping off Yemen’s coast. It was not clear whether any oil was leaking.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: A Houthi fighter on the beach in December, with the Galaxy Leader cargo ship, seized by the Houthis in November, in the background.

item.title: Sphen, Penguin Whose Gay Love Story Earned Global Fame, Dies
item.description: For six years, Sphen and Magic were devoted partners, adoptive parents and queer icons. After Sphen died this month at age 11, Magic began singing.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: Sphen, right, and Magic lead other penguins under a rainbow arch in their enclosure at Sea Life Sydney Aquarium.

item.title: Russia Pushes Forward in Ukraine’s East as Kursk Offensive Slows
item.description: The Ukrainians must defend a critical front in their country’s east, including the city of Pokrovsk, while trying to press forward in western Russia.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: A volunteer helping residents evacuate on Thursday from a village near Pokrovsk, eastern Ukraine, as Russian forces grind toward the city.
